stem: A client with Gram-negative sepsis is being managed with IV antibiotics. Based on the documentation in the Serial Coagulation & Perfusion Log, which finding indicates the development of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)?

options.text: The combination of low fibrinogen (92) and prolonged aPTT (74s)
The presence of Gram-negative bacteria in the blood

rationale.correct: This is **Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) (a1)**. DIC is a consumptive coagulopathy frequently triggered by sepsis. The definitive labs that separate DIC from simple sepsis or localized bleeding are **Low Fibrinogen** and **Prolonged PT/PTT** (a1). This shows that the body has 'used up' all its clotting factors, leading to the clinical finding of bleeding from 'everywhere' (IV sites, petechiae, urine). The high D-dimer confirms the accelerated breakdown of the tiny clots being formed throughout the microvasculature.
clinicalPearls: DIC = Clotting and Bleeding at the same time.
Treatment: 1. Fix the underlying cause (Antibiotics). 2. Replace what's missing (FFP, Cryoprecipitate, Platelets).
Priority safety: Protect from injury; no unnecessary punctures or IM injections.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Platelets (a3) as the definitive sign.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Platelets are low in many conditions (like simple Sepsis or HIT). **Fibrinogen** is the specific 'heavy hitter' in the DIC diagnosis because it indicates total factor consumption.

mnemonic.title: F-D-D
mnemonic.expansion: F-Fibrinogen falls. D-Dimer rises. D-Death is coming (unless you fix the sepsis).

exhibits.title: Nursing Assessment
exhibits.content: Current: Petechiae and purpura noted on the chest and thighs. Continuous 'oozing' noted from two old IV sites. Urine and NG drainage are moderately blood-tinged (guaiac positive).

exhibits.title: Vital Signs
exhibits.content: BP 88/52, HR 132, Temp 103.4°F. Client is pale and lethargic.
